Annotation: To open the film, a bomba song begins with a yubá rhythm. The song is “Estoy buscando un árbol que me dé sombra. The traditional tune then transitions into a salsa adaptation, signaling musical fusion. The accompanying image of the film depict bomba practitioners or bomberos/bomberas playing the barriles (bomba drums), dancing, depict a traditional casita, and show a tree growing, and its roots and seeds as fertilizing the earth.

Welmo E. Romero-Joseph (b. 1993) was a hip-hop MC, who is also known for his activism and values of social justice. In this clip, he sings in Spanish, rapping the following:
"Presuemiendo que mi gente se encuentre lista llega un cronista, protagonista de una historia
que le rinde culto al ritmo el tambor y la cadencia
dando esencia y vigencia a fuertes memorias
reclamando un espacio al interior de una cultura que en ocasiones ha olvidado el espelendor de su negrura"

English Translation “Assuming my people are ready, a chronicler arrives—protagonist of a story that pays homage to rhythm, to the drum and its cadence, giving essence and vitality to powerful memories, reclaiming a space within a culture that at times has forgotten the splendor of its Blackness."

A flamenco singer accompanies images and text that state: “La bomba y la plena son productos de fusiones musicales de la taína, la española y la africana, un ir y venir de influencias. Esta influencia afectaría toda la vida de esta isla.” Musical lyrcis are mostly unintelligible during this segment.

English Translation: “Bomba and plena are the products of musical fusions of Taíno, Spanish, and African traditions—an ebb and flow of influences. This influence would shape the entire life of the island.”

An electric guitar transitions into “Cuembe na’ma,” a bomba song presented here with a salsa-fusion adaptation. Flamenco singer Olga Tañón (A Puerto Rican singer known as the "Queen of Merengue" performs, accompanied by palmas (handclaps), while a bomba dancer is present. Traditional jomba jaleos are heard, along with interruptions from the barriles, creating a call-and-response between the palmas and the drums. Additional lyrics not originally part of “Cuembe na’ma” are included—such as “estamos tan angustiados”. The clips showcases highly virtuosic singing. The batey (or space in which bomba is performed) is located at an outdoor location and used modern sound equipment. Mar Anthony also has a small solo during this performance segment. Giovanni Hidalgo is on the barriles.

"Agustito"
Soy de la calle y la puerta de atrás
Donde está el ritmo caliente
Aquí todo el mundo quiere gozar
Ya sé que ésta es mi gente
El humo de un joy me hace volar
Aquí no hay noches ni día
aquí no hay noches ni día, nos reiremos
en la tempestad;
no quiero vida tranquila,
sé que todo en esta vida pasará
y yo nunca cambiaré.
Ahora que estamos tan agustito,
tan agustito, tan agustito, tú ves...
Variation of Original Lyrics that serves a narrative function
Para que sepas en verdad quién soy, de dónde vengo y hacia dónde voy. Voy a contarte una historia, lo que debe saber la sangre que corre. Mis pedazas es pura cera, te dire porque. (Llamada)"que ataca a José"
The song is most likely a merengue.
Vocalist Lucecita Benitez sings a part of "Una Noche En Borinquen" from her album Desilución

Welmo intervenes once again with a narrative rap transition. His rap declares: “No pretendo ser el reemplazo de voces ausentes, ni decir que mi oratoria es la única referencia. Baile bomba, toques de plena—lo que digo vale la pena. Lo importante es la conexión del pasado con el presente.”\
English Translation:
“I don’t pretend to replace absent voices, nor claim that my speech is the only reference. Dance bomba, play plena—what I say is worth hearing. What matters is the connection between past and present.”

Discussion of the sugar cane plantations
Epifanio Izatrrio

Ruth Fernandez sings "Negra triste." A song which discusses a Black woman who loses her love and suffers due to this loss.
"Ya Negro Murió" or "Negra Triste" (Aguadilla)
Negra triste, porque ya el negro murió, porque ya el negro durmió, mas nunca va a disfrutar el guateque— solo quedó la negra.
La negra no cesa de llorar, ¡ay, su dolor! Negra está triste, negra sola llora su pena, llora su pena y su dolor.
El negro que tanto quiso está en los reinos de Dios. Negra está triste, está llorando su amor, está llorando a su negro, su negro que tanto amó.

English Translation
"Sad Black Woman"
Sad Black woman, because the Black man has died, because the Black man has slept, never again to enjoy the celebration— only the Black woman remains.
She does not stop crying, oh, her sorrow. She is sad, alone she weeps her grief, she weeps her sorrow and her pain.
The Black man she loved so deeply is now in the realms of God. She is heartbroken, mourning her love, mourning her Black man, the one she loved so much.

Annotation: Petra Cepeda states that "era la repuesta popular a la musica y la danza de la aristocracia." ("It was the popular response to the music and dance of the aristocracy").

Welmo raps: "Me levanto tomo aire sigo el ritmo me despejo en la sangre de una raza que se mira al espejo con las manos negras manos que se lanzan sobre el cuero. Canto, baile, ritmo. Canto, baile, ritmo"

English Translation:
"I rise, I breathe, I follow the rhythm. I clear my mind in the blood of a race that looks into the mirror with Black hands—hands that strike the drum. Song, dance, rhythm. Song, dance, rhythm."

"Estoy buscando un arbol appears again

Welmo raps again:
La sensación del gusto, el roce de la tela y el sudor pasean juntos. Aumentan los latidos, temperatura en fiebre que le curó. No se calle, pues si callo no soy libre. Llamando y respuesta, resistencia y osadía, Aun con las cadenas, 24 horas al día. Mi voz viaja activa, sabiendo que quizás No vuelva a ver la luz del día. Tambor, dame el ser del sonido de tu alma. Tambor, cuida mi sueño con tu dulce melodía.

English Translation
The sensation of taste, the brush of fabric, and sweat walk together. Heartbeats rise, fevered temperature healed. Do not be silent—for if I am silent, I am not free. Call and response, resistance and boldness, Even with chains, 24 hours a day. My voice travels, alive, Knowing that perhaps I may never see the light of day again. Drum, give me the being of your soul’s sound. Drum, guard my sleep with your sweet melody

Flagpole Stick Flagpole stick, Bedframe rod — not with me. You’ve got a long face, Like the mule at the clothesline. And your legs are skinny, Like a sandpiper by the sea.
Flagpole stick, Bedframe rod — not with me. You’ve got a long face, Like the mule at the clothesline. You’ve got skinny legs, Like a sandpiper by the sea.
And you learn to show respect, Learn to respect me. Don’t be a vine, Like a sandpiper by the sea.

Possible Brazilian instrument; cuica
Images of hip-hop or breakdance occurring in a batey

The vocalist is uncredited in the film but the style resembles that of Residente/Calle 13. The singer might also be the rapper-singer Welmo who appears throughout the film. In this segment, an electric guitar melody can be heard, and it transitions into the following partial song. The song "soy libre" of unknown author is political in nature commenting on the nature of freedom, and colonialism in Puerto Rico by stating that the author is "free like the rivers." It's a powerful close to a film that touches on themes colonialism rather sparingly.

"Soy Libre"
Y soy libre, Libre como el río que en el mar desemboca,
Libre las palabras que saltan de mi boca. Libre decido y alcanzo lo que quiero, Y aunque presto esté mi cuerpo, Es mi mente la que elevo. Libre es el aire que respiro Desde el momento en que nazco Hasta el último suspiro. Libre como el suelo de una isla que se expande, Libre es mi pueblo, y ante balas no se rinde.
Libre, y soy libre.
Libre, y soy libre"
